F20.name: Note-Taking Assistance
F20.reason: may have difficulty with concentration and auditory processing, making it challenging to simultaneously listen, comprehend, and take comprehensive notes
F20.recommendation: be provided with a peer note-taker or be permitted to audio-record lectures to ensure they can review the material accurately.

F20.name: Flexible Attendance
F20.reason: may experience fluctuations in symptoms that can impact their ability to attend class consistently
F20.recommendation: have an agreed-upon number of excused absences without penalty and be able to obtain materials for any missed classes.

F20.name: Reduced Distraction Environment for Exams
F20.reason: is susceptible to sensory overstimulation and distracting internal thoughts, which can interfere with performance in a standard testing environment
F20.recommendation: take all exams in a separate, quiet room to minimize distractions.

F25.name: Deadline and Exam Flexibility
F25.reason: experiences cyclical mood and thought disruptions that can unpredictably affect their ability to complete work and prepare for exams
F25.recommendation: have the ability to request extensions on assignments and, in coordination with the professor, reschedule an exam if symptoms are acute.

F25.name: Structured Feedback
F25.reason: benefits from clear, concrete, and structured feedback to aid with focus and reduce potential for misinterpretation during periods of cognitive stress
F25.recommendation: receive assignment feedback in writing and have the opportunity to ask clarifying questions with the instructor or a TA.

F31.name: Attendance and Deadline Flexibility
F31.reason: experiences significant variations in energy, concentration, and motivation due to mood episodes (manic and depressive)
F31.recommendation: be granted flexibility on attendance and assignment deadlines, with a clear communication plan established with the professor.

F31.name: Breaks During Class and Exams
F31.reason: may experience racing thoughts or psychomotor agitation during manic phases, or fatigue and cognitive slowing during depressive phases
F31.recommendation: be permitted to take short, unobtrusive breaks during long classes or exams as needed to manage symptoms.

296.5.name: Reduced Course Load
296.5.reason: may find a full course load overwhelming while managing symptoms, which can exacerbate mood episodes
296.5.recommendation: be permitted to take a reduced course load without affecting their status as a student.

301.13.name: Attendance and Deadline Flexibility
301.13.reason: experiences fluctuating moods and energy levels that, while less severe than bipolar disorder, can still impact consistency and performance
301.13.recommendation: have flexibility with deadlines and attendance, allowing them to manage their work around periods of low mood or heightened energy.

F32.name: Flexible Deadlines
F32.reason: may face challenges with motivation, energy levels, and concentration, making it difficult to complete assignments on a fixed schedule
F32.recommendation: be able to negotiate deadline extensions with professors, especially for larger projects, when symptoms are present.

F32.name: Support with Participation
F32.reason: may find it difficult to engage in classroom discussions due to low energy or feelings of worthlessness
F32.recommendation: be allowed to participate in alternative ways, such as through online discussion boards or one-on-one meetings with the instructor.

F40.name: Alternative to In-Class Presentations
F40.reason: experiences intense fear and anxiety related to public speaking or being in front of a large group
F40.recommendation: be provided with an alternative to oral presentations, such as a written paper, a pre-recorded presentation, or a one-on-one presentation with the instructor.

F40.00.name: Preferential Seating
F40.00.reason: may experience intense anxiety or panic in crowded spaces or situations where they feel 'trapped'
F40.00.recommendation: be allowed to sit near an exit to ease feelings of confinement and allow for a quick departure if symptoms escalate.

300.22.name: Preferential Seating

300.22.recommendation: be allowed to sit near an exit to ease feelings of confinement and allow for a quick departure if symptoms escalate.

F41.name: Extended Time on Exams
F41.reason: may experience cognitive difficulties, such as racing thoughts or trouble concentrating, due to anxiety
F41.recommendation: receive 1.5x the standard time on all exams and timed assignments.

F41.1.name: Flexible Deadlines
F41.1.reason: experiences symptoms of anxiety that can be exacerbated by rigid deadlines, impacting their ability to produce work that reflects their knowledge
F41.1.recommendation: be permitted to request a 2-3 day extension on assignments when needed, in communication with the professor

F41.1.name: Ability to Take Breaks
F41.1.reason: may experience episodes of heightened anxiety or panic during long lectures or exams
F41.1.recommendation: be allowed to step out of the classroom or testing environment for short breaks without penalty, as needed to manage symptoms

300.09.name: Extended Time on Exams

300.11.name: Flexible Attendance

F42.2.name: Flexibility on Timed Assignments

F42.2.recommendation: be granted extended time (1.5x or 2x) on all timed exams and in-class assignments

F90.1.recommendation: be permitted to use quiet fidget tools in the classroom to aid concentration.

F91.name: Behavioral Contracts
F91.reason: benefits from clear, predictable rules and consequences to help manage behavior
F91.recommendation: establish a behavioral contract with clear expectations for classroom conduct and assignment completion, co-created with the student and instructor.

F91.name: Positive Reinforcement
F91.reason: responds well to positive reinforcement for meeting behavioral and academic goals
F91.recommendation: implement a system that acknowledges and rewards progress towards positive classroom engagement.

312.8.name: Behavioral Contracts
312.8.reason: benefits from clear, predictable rules and consequences to help manage behavior
312.8.recommendation: establish a behavioral contract with clear expectations for classroom conduct and assignment completion, co-created with the student and instructor.

312.8.name: Positive Reinforcement
312.8.reason: responds well to positive reinforcement for meeting behavioral and academic goals
312.8.recommendation: implement a system that acknowledges and rewards progress towards positive classroom engagement.

313.89.name: Choice in Assignments
313.89.reason: may exhibit oppositional behavior when feeling a lack of control
313.89.recommendation: be provided with choices in assignment topics or formats, where possible, to increase buy-in and cooperation.

313.89.name: Non-Confrontational Redirection
313.89.reason: can escalate in response to direct confrontation
313.89.recommendation: be redirected using non-confrontational language and offered a chance to cool down in a designated space if behavior becomes disruptive.

312.3.name: Cooling-Off Period
312.3.reason: may experience sudden outbursts of anger or aggression
312.3.recommendation: be allowed to leave the classroom for a pre-arranged 'cooling-off' space when they feel their anger escalating, without penalty.

315.00.name: Use of Assistive Technology
315.00.reason: has specific deficits in reading, writing, or math that can be supported by technology
315.00.recommendation: be permitted to use text-to-speech, speech-to-text software, or calculators as appropriate for their specific learning disability.

315.00.name: Alternative Formats for Materials
315.00.reason: may struggle with standard print materials
315.00.recommendation: be provided with course materials in an alternative format, such as audiobooks, large print, or digital text that can be used with assistive technology.
